fileDesc.publicationStmt: Maryland Institute of Technology in the Humanities College Park MD <date when=2018-4-3">March 4 2018>

body.p: The Negro college woman no longer waits for acceptance by white society. She has her own culture, according to a Federal City College official.

This was the brunt of the speech given by BarbaraHatton, as­
sistant dean of student services at FCC, to an attentive audience of about 600 at a Panhellenic con­
ference in the chapel Saturday morning.</p of about 600 at a Panhellenic con­
ference in the chapel Saturday morning.

Speaking without notes, Miss Hatton attempted to give the sorority girls an idea of where the greek system stands in re­
lation to racial integration.
“Rushing out and bringing people (blacks) into a white thing isn’t wanted anymore,” Miss Hatton said.

According to her, black col­
lege women now have their own concept of beauty and culture and it has nothing to do with the “narrow concepts we get from TV."

Black women do not want to be accepted as equal,Miss Hat
­ ton said.

“We want to be accepted as we are; black with our own way of doing things. I don’t like to explain away black folks. An explanation shouldn’t be needed.” An attitude generally confused with good race relations is to “go around loving everybody,” she said.
“You can’t possibly love everybody you meet. What is needed in any relationship is pride and skills and we’ve (blacks) got to bring these in. That’s what we’re doing now.”

Miss Hatton concluded by say­
ing that the important thing for each sorority to do is to examine its feelings and see what is real and meaningful in its social and racial relations.

The speech was preceded by a poetry reading by Adwole, a poet from Afro-American Living Arts of Washington. The poems ranged in message from utopian brother­
hood to black militancy and from social Injustice to intermarriage.

The African Heritage Dancers and Drummers performed three dances; one used as a greeting, another performed at weddings and one in honor of a great war
f­ rior.

The conference also hosted a preview of the Black Student Uhion dancers’recital. The theme of the program was history of the American Negro, from his comfort in a native culture to his search for identity now.

“The conference was meant to expose the girls to this cul­
ture,” said DebbieJennings, sec­
ond vice president of Panhel. “We don’t know yet how it will affect each sorority’s poli­
cies.”

One sorority girl commented, “Some of the houses are really for integration and others are dead against it. But I think we’ll have some black greeks next year whether some girls want it or not. We’re under a lot of pressure.”
